summary: Linguistics professor Louise Banks (Amy Adams) leads an elite team of investigators when gigantic spaceships touch down in 12 locations around the world. As nations teeter on the verge of global war, Banks and her crew must race against time to find a way to communicate with the extraterrestrial visitors. Hoping to unravel the mystery, she takes a chance that could threaten her life and quite possibly all of mankind.

reviews.content: Interesting visual effects for about 2 minutes. A very bad story that rips off a lot of previously done better concepts and makes them shallow and boring.

Thematically and visually ravishing, the excellently directed Arrival provides thought-provoking storytelling and a wondrous performance from Amy Adams, even though the conclusion isn't fully rewarding and it has some filler aspects to it.
Could have used a bit more aliens and higher stakes, but the soundtrack and design are really good.

Arrival is by far the best movie covering the subject of ufo's and aliens. This movie is so beautiful from beginning to end.  Even the music is special.  You won't find the normal action you would see in a sci-fi movie, but it is more interesting with every scene. Don't worry, there are still scenes that make you nervous :)

This is also the most realistic movie regarding what would happen if our friends from outer space really did land on Earth. Though, Contact is right there as well. 

The movie shows how easy it is for humans to make assumptions that lead unnecessary disaster. It also shows the importance of language and understanding each other, even when it may seem impossible. 

The cast is small so you can focus on the theme of the movie and really think, "What would I do if I had to translate a language from an alien race that sounds nothing like ours?!"  Amy makes it look easy. 

Amy Adams delivers such an amazing performance and dominates in this mostly male cast. Her role in this film really inspired me. 

If you are looking for big special effects and a war between man and extraterrestrial, this may not be your favorite movie. I still think you should watch it because it really does make you think. 

If you don't watch it, the main point is that humanity needs to work together to accomplish the goals we need to survive. This is OUR planet and eventually we will have to put aside our differences for the greater good before we destroy everything due to ego.

OK so what I'm about to say is very simple, but i'll stand by it because it's true: If you like fantastic movies, you really need to see Arrival. You see I'm a huge fan of the UFO topic in general, I think it's extremely fascinating. I'm not sure how I went 7 years without seeing Arrival, but I'm sure glad I did.

Yes, Arrival is a movie about aliens visiting earth in the form of 12 enormous, mysterious alien craft. But to just call Arrival a "UFO movie" is not doing it anywhere near enough justice. The movies central themes are about human nature, how we perceive others and how we look at life and the way we communicate in general.

Amy Adams has never been better as the reluctant language expert called aboard to to figure out what the mysterious beings want with us. Jeremy Renner is also very good here as well as the scientist brought aboard, but it's Adams who shines. I'd call it a must-see.

Beautifully fascinating yet intriguingly mysterious. Slow pace at times but provocative plot somehow indulge emotion into the mix. The next big thing has arrived.
A wonderful movie! Exceptional acting and a superb story line.

Superb direction. I thought it's ridiculous in the beginning, but gradually it became intriguing and thrilling. The film holds unique atmosphere, the sensory imagery is over the top. Creative and humane. Don't overlook.
Incredible and visually stunning movie!

I had been planning to watch this since 2016, and I only saw it today - in February 2023. It is such an unbelievable masterpiece that it still felt like it came from the future and wasn't something I was so late to witness.
Utterly mind-blowing!

Arrival is a breath of fresh air among modern Hollywood. From the delicately handled symbolism, to the masterful re-interpretation of a timeless story, to the performances of Adams and Renner, to the incredible score by the late Jóhannsson - something of a magnum opus for his film work - Arrival is everything a film should be, and sets the bar for what we should see more of today.
Solid movie. It's emotional, it's structured good (maybe a little slow). The only problem is I wish it had some levity. The tone throughout the entire movie is painted one color: melancholy gray.

An absolute masterpiece. It is rare to find a film which makes you think about life itself. The film could be described as an ‘alien invasion movie', but it would be a grave oversimplification and a massive disservice to put it in the same category as the likes of hit-and-miss sci-fi movies including Independence Day and Cloverfield. The basic plot is aliens visiting, but the film is a lot more than that. This film explores love, loss and the very essence of humanity and what it means to be human.

I wish that I could go back and watch this movie again for the first time. It is intelligent, complicated and balanced. There are thought-provoking questions throughout the film and that comes from delicate filmmaking. 

The direction is crisp, the score is poignant and the acting is excellent (Amy Adams was snubbed from the Oscar nom). My first time watching this film was a singular theater experience. I was (and still am) truly blown away by Arrival. 

Best Character: Louise
Best Scene: A Proper Introduction
Best Quote: "Despite knowing the journey and where it leads, I embrace it and I welcome every moment of it." - Louise
Best Piece of Score: "On The Nature of Daylight"
Oof, that was Rotten
Best of Movies/TV Series Collection
One of the most emotional and stunning films Ive ever saw in my life. Amy Adams is just delicate as shes is fierce.
What a slow movie. Great effects and great acting. But that’s about it. The story was a let down and do was the ending.

More than the average alien invasion story, Arrival is an emotional, thought-provoking film with its interesting concept of time. The amazing visuals and Amy Adam's performance was really something else.
Interesting, esoteric sci fi.
I enjoyed the lighting and storyline. I also appreciated that the aliens were not made to seem like bad guys
One of my all-time favorites. Plot twist is heartbreaking yet inspirational.
The best sound mixing ever done in a movie!
Slowish but compelling and thought provoking.  At times, more questions than answers, but worth it.  Visually fantastic, good characters, great performance.
Layers and metaphors. A film that tells many stories about perception while being perceived.
Could have been better but original
Successful portayal of emotions while being a scifi movie

Arrival is a very good sci-fi movie but it is a great movie about life, love, and the human spirit.  Movies can be almost magical in making you look at life and the world in a completely different way and Arrival delivers on all fronts.  A thoroughly enjoyable experience.
Incredible movie that proves sci-fi movies don't need next level action sequences or crazy flashy effects to rise on top of their genre.

Emotionally moving, beautifully acted, and wonderfully crafted, "Arrival" stands as the best of Denis Villeneuve and possible one of the best sci-fi movies to ever be produced. From its stellar soundtrack to its absolutely perfect cast, this film blew me away and shocked me in all the best ways. Would absolutely recommend!
Illogical and boring.

Amazing storytelling with a cast that is great for this movie. Especially the acting of Amy Adams and Forest Whitaker! This is so much more than a normal sci-fi movie, so very deeply emotional, with a perfect soundtrack and great picture.

As a non-american, american films often feel to me not so deep. I read critics using words such as mind-bending and emotional. I didn't find it was. It was interesting. The shots were beautiful. It is interesting the slightly explored ideas of time not being lineal. It gives hope that younger generations will watch this and imbue the underlying goodness rather than mililtary inflexible limited thinking. I enjoyed this film, but I doubt I will remember it in a few months. It feels as if it will be dated very soon. It's good but limited. It feels pseudo intelligent.
I loved this movie. The best part about it is that it is a satire in that it presents the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) as good. LOL!
Arrival nails it at every level, providing an emotional story and a compelling sci-fi plot.  The plot is a slow burn without much action, but viewers looking to engage their brains will be rewarded.

Villeneuve riesce a portare la sua consueta ed estrema eleganza nel mondo della fantascienza, traendo spunto da un racconto molto originale, mette in piedi un perfetto e credibile meccanismo di linguaggio in cui è impossibile non comprendere l'abilità e la precisione con viene rappresentato tutto.
Il passaggio centrale del film forse è leggermente lento rispetto alle due estremità; fatica maggiormente a tenere le fila anche se risulta necessario visto l'inserimento dei flash forward che rendono il finale entusiasmante seppure complesso; quasi a connotazione "Nolaniana" per come il Cerchio viene chiuso.
La fotografia e gli effetti sonori con il loro montaggio sono sublimi.
Amy Adams una delle più talentuose attrici in circolazione.
Immediately boring. Then continually boring. In finality boring. Totally boring.

Arrival is different from many other sci-fi movies. The way in which communication between humans and aliens is approached is incredible. It still manages to carry the great tension of the mystery behind its arrival.

So underrated, so beautiful, this film will leave you speechless with deep sense of beautiful melancholy. One of the best movies ever, more so among others in it's genre, even better than interstellar (although probably not in the aspect of theoretical science, but in every other aspects!)
Exquisite performance by Amy Adams. Superb story and production. Both the emotional and the aspect of the unknown makes this a masterpiece!

I generally tend to suppress my emotions--given that so much media tries get cheap emotional reactions--but this ending really got to me.  It's terrifying and beautiful at the same time.  Add to that a wonderful science fiction story about trying to communicate with aliens that actually addresses the difficulties and consequence of doing so, yes please.

This is quite an eery film - I felt it seemed almost more like a documentary than a sci-fi drama film at one point, with a narrator explaining to the viewer what had been learnt about the mysterious new beings from outer space who have apparently taken up residence in a number of locations on Earth. I liked the nostalgic flashbacks shown, a reminder of childrens curiosity and wonder when faced with seeing certain things for the first time. Its a relatively atmospheric film, with looming music used in the background, not dissimilar to that present in other previous sci-fi films, most notably Close Encounters of the Third Kind. It also reminded me somewhat of Jodie Foster in the film Contact from the 1990s.

Its a somewhat deep film that makes you think about how threats are handled, at a global level, the responses by various governments and the like. If anything, I found it refreshing that in this instance, the US didn't exactly go in 'all guns blazing' and I appreciated that the main character, Louise Banks, tries very hard to understand and see things from the unknowns' point of view. I don't think I can say much more but suffice to say, I recommend this film.
First new concept for a while

With an incredible and unforgettable performance for the always great and undeniably unjusticed Amy Adams, a marvelous sound mixing and editing (the aliens sound is for the ages), as with the perfect score from Jóhann Jóhannsson (a tragic loss for sure), this story is well built, well adapted and directed by the master Denis Villeneuve. A sure recommendation.
5 years ago- A mindbending plot with impeccable writing, strong acting, and beautiful directing.

This is one of my favorite films ever made.  Everything was perfect.  I really loved the cinematography.  The story is so thought-provoking.  We all know how our story ends but our protagonist saw it first hand and still decided to move forward despite knowing sadness lied ahead for her.  The music was haunting as well.  The last great film I've seen.

What a super show that exposes humanity to alien intruders, who say if they help us now, we can help them 3,000 years later.   And all of this falls on one lady and her male friend which makes this movie a *4* star film!!!!

Arrival, ist ein Science-Fiction-Film besonderer Art. Die Geschichte (Drehbuch Eric Heisserer) ist bereit uns zu fesseln. Die Musik von Jóhann Jóhannsson gibt uns eine tiefe Atmosphäre. Und Denis Villeneuve (Regie) hat sie in hervorragende Bilder umgesetzt.

SPOILERS My main problem with this film is the ridiculousness of seeing though time by learning a language. I was immensely excited when I started the movie and it appeared to be about linguistics and how we really would communicate with extra-terrestrials. Imagine my colossal disappointment when suddenly it was all about woo woo fortune teller powers. In fairness, I believe this story is likely much more organically told through print, and will be reading the story the film is based on. The acting was well done, and the visuals were sharp and eerie (a rare combination these days). Despite these positive aspects, the concept being too silly and the irritation of a linguistic cock-tease were the determining factor in my score.

Probably one of the best films I've ever seen. Thought provoking, emotional, intelligent sci-fi with a satisfying ending that will leave you blown away and heartbroken at the same time. Easily repeatable as you spot something new with each viewing.

A film that, by using aliens, gets at what it means to be human, the nature of language and communication, and the very real tendency to construe unfamiliarity as a threat. Arrival also shows, with a lot of tension and drama, that the solution to miscommunication is more communication and a commitment to the idea that most people (or aliens) are not out to destroy you. 

I couldn't quite go for the last portion of the film where the purpose of the alien language was revealed, but in general I think Villeneuve has made yet another excellent film.

Arrival has shot right up to the top of my all time favourite films. Elegiac and profound but also thrilling and engrossing. The Max Richter music, the colour palate and especially Amy Adams, criminally overlooked for an Oscar in one of her most outstanding performances. Wonderful.
Great attempt that just fell short of the mark. Better writing and plot would have made this movie a success. Just overall mediocre. Not good, not bad, just in the middle.

Yeah, this is better than CATS.

This movie is fantastic!

The story is very interesting and told in a clever way through science and politics instead of the overused premise of aliens destroying the planet for domination. Amy Adams delivered another brilliant performance that earned her an Academy Award nomination but not a win. She's definitely overdue for an Oscar.

A must watch for independent thinkers and people who value the everlasting perspectives of the cosmos. Challenging to understand but it makes it that much more amazing.
This is not your typical alien movie, it's much more realistic. It's actually about communicating with the aliens. Not sure what to think of the ending thoug.

unfortunately it was just okay

This movie is fantastic. The performance of Amy Adams is unparalleled, and the approach to the storyline is fantastic as well. It is a cerebral movie and may have suffered from marketing as a Sci-Fi action drama, but this is deeper than a typical alien invasion shoot 'em up drama. The pieces are laid out during the first act and leave the viewer confused, trying to put them together, and when they eventually come together it snaps so neatly and satisfyingly. This is a fantastic movie that has more in common with films like Inception than Independence Day. In my opinion, one of the best films of the year.
I am as confused as you are (in a good way). I think this is what Memento wants to be but cannot be.

An amazing movie!!I loved it!!

This movie is a creative and beautiful sci-fi film which actually manages to provoke emotions from viewers, at least it did in my case, and seeing by other reviews, any others feel the same way. The movie is never boring, nor slow; throughout it constantly provokes thought and reaches into your heart. It is simply beautiful. The shots, action, and its carefully, elegantly and dare I say again beautiful portrayal of language and its affect on all life. Despite being critically acclaimed, 'Arrival' is another one of those films that is praised to the heavens with critics but has wildly divided audiences judging from the nature of both the positivity and negativity. Though it has to be said that the positive reviewers have been far more mature than the negative ones, many of which to me being disgustingly condescending.

'Arrival' is a very different sci-fi film, and one can definitely see why people will love it and be moved by it as well as seeing why people will hate it and be alienated. To me, 'Arrival' is not as good as reputed and is not a masterpiece, but even if it didn't do much for me it would have gotten a 4 at least. From personal opinion there are far worse films out there that are far more deserving of 1/10, and it would be insulting to put 'Arrival' down there with them. Even if the film didn't much for me, the good things would still be acknowledged and there would be real effort to be respectful of other people's opinions regardless of agreeing or disagreeing with them rather than being insulting and inventing ridiculous and untrue conspiracy theories. Those who hated it do need to grow up and start accepting that not everybody hates this film and that those who loved it are being genuine, and no being angry at being disappointed by it is not an excuse. Coming from a younger film lover than most on this site who's autistic and disabled but those have not gotten in the way of being understanding of people's opinions, what's your excuse?

Back to my thoughts on the film, 'Arrival' is a meditatively paced film, and is not an action filled or jam packed with constant narrative. While this may understandably alienate viewers, neither of these are necessarily bad things especially when there are great to masterpiece films that are the same. Of the four films seen of Denis Villeneuve so far, 'Arrival' may be my least favourite, and his most polarising, least violent and most gentle, but that is just testament to how very good 'Prisoners' is and how fantastic 'Incendies' and 'Sicario' are.

The criticisms are understandable and am in agreement with some. It does drag in the middle act, softening and slacking too much. It does get confusing in the later stages, where things can get ridiculous and predictable.

Forest Whittaker and particularly Michael Stuhlbarg's characters are underutilised and underwritten with both having very little to do, the two do make the most of their roles one has to give them that.

However, 'Arrival' does look wonderful. This is particularly true in Bradford Young's cinematography, being fluid and its tactile quality is of sheer beauty. It's beautifully and atmospherically designed and lit, the special effects have grand spectacle and the editing is some of the best of its year.

Johann Johannsson's music score is another standout, it has a haunting creepiness and has a heart-pulsating and emotional beat. It not only adds a huge amount to the film, it also enhances it. Denis Villeneuve's direction is his most subtle and least hard-hitting, which is not only a good thing but the right thing, the approach he gave to 'Prisoners' and 'Sicario' would have ruined an atmosphere that's the complete opposite.

In terms of how it's written, 'Arrival' is not perfect but it has a movingly raw emotion, thoughtfulness, subtly suspenseful mystery and gives a compelling realism to its character especially the protagonist. Likewise the story (yes there is one), with a poignant emotion and a clever and powerful, if perhaps not the most logical, twist.

The acting is one of 'Arrival's' best assets, all round it's very good even if some characters are better realised than others. Amy Adams in particular is astounding, she has rarely been more poignant. Jeremy Renner also underplays effortlessly.

All in all, divisive film but count me as one of the people who liked it but in an appreciation way than a loved it way. 7/10 Bethany Cox

Out of the countless films I've watched, from various genres, directors, actors and award winners. My mind always jumps back to this one. I am still unable to translate my feeling towards this masterpiece into words - and I don't think I'll ever be able to.
I'm not here to feed any egos. They really thought they did something here. And they did, but They could have done it so much faster. For a movie about time it sure does drag.

I've seen many "alien" movies in my time but this one is quite unique, it sums up for me what I think would happen if aliens came to earth. The story is a beautiful one, although somewhat somber at times. I was mostly impressed by the imagination used to create language in this; many writers have created languages for many of reasons, however this really takes our understanding of language outside the box, to try and create a believable non human communication system. It was also very well shot, and perfectly paced. Definitely underrated.

A riveting story with excellent characterization and complex storytelling, it's the rare movie that treats its audience like intelligent beings. Deliberately withholding information at points to let the viewer fill in blanks and figure things out before they happen on screen, Arrival is an example of an original concept excellently brought to life.

By the end we are stunned! 
What is time? And what will we do with the time we have? 
Beginning is the end, the end is the beginning
What a filmmaking!

The sound is also fantastic. The story is really good, but it suffers from a pretty heavy handed treatment, especially towards the end.

This is a must-see alien encounter film. It is a thinking person kind of flick. Great acting, even pacing, some action and great special FX with very unique aliens that are here to instruct and guide us.

By far my favorite movie, it plays with so many scientific concepts and beautifully delivers the message of unity and understanding that it strives for. The aliens are unsettling yet calming it really puts the audience on the edge of their seats. 5/5 stars super engaging!

I watched this way to late at night to understand fully, but still ugly cried multiple times. I think I have a maternal attachment to Amy Adams, seeing her slightly sad makes me want to die. 
This film is beautiful, thoughtful, timely, and enthralling. To wholly appreciate will require re-watches, but that won't feel like a chore.

Arrival is an out of the ordinary sci-fi movie, with its most essential focus being a mother and other "real" things. Denis Villeneuve made a masterpiece in more than one ways. The imagery is monumental and simple the same time, emphasizing that here not the CGI, the spectacle or the pace is the major driving force of this story, but the people themselves in it. Besides this it also offers a stunning plot with some twists.

I feel strongly that this film is a masterclass in film-making, as it is able to merge the epic scope of the sci-fi genre, with a story that ultimately centres around motherhood.
Without spoiling the film, I'd summarise it as an
exploration of the human condition and what it means to be a mother, wrapped under the guise of an alien blockbuster. On a cinematic level, this film is near perfect. Denis Villeneuve manages to create a synthesis of the real-world environment with excellent CGI, creating a more grounded,
realistic alien film that isn't very common. The score is unbeatable, with the heart-wrenching melody of Max Richter's "On the nature of daylight" swelling in the epilogue, emphasising the heart-wrenching climax of the film.
Of course, Amy Adams is superb (as always), as she so fluently, pardon the pun, portrays a confident linguist who creates a realistic balance between her career and her motherhood. This is an incredible character that Amy Adams fantastically portrays. Jeremy Renner is great too,
as is Forest Whitaker, but Amy Adams is definitely the star here.
To conclude, I implore you to watch this film! It is
groundbreaking, as it has not only completely redefined the sci-fi genre for me, but it has reshaped my philosophy regarding mortality and love, and made me think of things in different ways. The film forces you to delve deep into
your own life, it forces you to confront your feelings and your regrets, yet you're never taken out of the film - you remain completely immersed in Villeneuve's frighteningly authentic world. I never expected a film that on the surface seemed to be about the arrival of aliens, to instead stir my
emotions in a way that very rarely happens with a film.
Unwatchable. Boring. Slow. I tried three times to watch this and couldn't. I LOVE science fiction but this was like watching paint dry. I disagree with the praise heaped upon this "film".
Extremely short-paced, felt like most of the movie was empty without a real driving story. I would have hoped for more action.

It was sci-fi but more FIction than SCIence. At least it was honest enough to ask initially "whence did they come, moreover how did they arrive here: Faster than light travel?" But then it sidetracked into impossible fantasies about time-travel or illusions of it. In short: Forget it; -Do not waste your time watching this film.

I have never had a movie make me stop for 30 minutes after and really contemplate the actions on the characters on the level I had to with this movie. To make the choices she made. To decide it was worth it. It's absolutely beautiful and heartbreaking. This movie is incredible. A gift.

HEAVY SPOILERS
An impressively complex yet comprehensive Science Fiction/Thriller story that doubles as a commentary on the importance of language. As foreshadowed by the protagonists Louise (Amy Adams) initially interaction with her co-lead Ian (Jeremy Renner) this is an exploration on the universal necessity of communication between sentient creatures. This is inclusive of not only humans and aliens but of humanity itself. The film also successfully presents an argument for why language is the most important weapon. Not to hurt or destroy but to defuse a conflict and mutually benefit everyone. Several factors come into play that raise the stakes of the movie. The first is the inability to communicate which plays out a number of different ways among the nations. Fear and paranoia are exploited by both the media and internet personalities which leads to protests and an assassination attempt later in the film. Pressure is placed on the governments to give answers they don't have. Thus tensions are placed on relationships between the military authority and Louise which slowly escalates and crescendos at the end and almost results in the death of our protagonists. The next factor is miscommunication which plays out as the alien language translating to "gift weapon" to each major location the aliens landed. This causes mistrust and fear between the world powers and they cut off communication for each other. Slowly but surely they begin to mobilize against the aliens believing them to want planetary control. Louise frantically tries to deescalate the situation to no avail. She knowing communication is the best way to solve this and believing the aliens to be friendly takes matters into her own hands and goes to talk to the aliens herself. Entering the chamber she  exposes herself to their atmospheric accommodations and talks face to...head? With one of the aliens whom she has come to know. She learns that they do indeed wish to gift them all a weapon but the weapon is not a scientific advancement or a destructive tool of conquest. Each power was given a piece of their language. Before departing Louise is given their entire language by the alien and when she returns she realizes she can understand it. She also begins to realize something else. Throughout the film we see what we thought were flashbacks to Louise's life and the death of her daughter. But it turns out that the film utilizes the theory that language determines the way your brain thinks and see's the world. Using this they introduce the concept that the alien language is a palindrome. Its the same backwards as it is forwards. Because of these things Louise is not having flash backs but flash forwards due to her increasing exposure to their language. Now she is able to see how everything in her life will play out and manipulate time to gain access to the phone number of the leading force of hostility towards the aliens. Using language she is able to reach him in an emotional place due to her ability to hear what she said in the future and prevent the attack on the aliens. Using only her words and the capabilities of language she prevents a major military conflict. The film wraps up with a corny but cute "I wouldn't change a thing" moment that is flipped on its head between our two leads as Louise is literally choosing to not change a single decision she has yet to make. However I will say she is able to see her own divorce in the future and it is implied she allowed things to happen the same way so that leaves me questioning why she would choose to go down the same path and not try and prevent it. But I suppose she can only remember the future not feel it in the moment so perhaps the nuance is that she has fallen in love with him currently and knows someday things won't be the same and she will fall out of love. It is human nature to do something that you desire despite knowing it will only end in pain so I suppose it does make sense but it also could be because she wants to experience the existence of her daughter and all the love and happiness that she has brought but also has yet to bring. Brings up a lot of ethical questions of selfishness and selflessness, is she being selfish in going down the same path or selfless in giving her daughter life even for a short time. Either way this is a movie that rewards thinking and knows how to subvert expectations in a satisfying way. In addition it presents a compelling argument about language and an entertaining exploration of a potentially possible scenario someday. I just wish the visuals weren't so cold and gray. It felt very bleak and for me that just makes it less appealing to ever revisit. But things are rarely perfect and this was still a hit on the nail for me. Give it a watch if it sounds like your thing.

I cannot get enough of this movie. The mood and tone are set right away, and pull you into a fantastic watch. Not only were the ideas there, but they were executed perfectly. Arrival is one of those movies that will leave you thinking about the story long after the credits roll.

Seriously overrated, I think. A boring, low pace movie with no action and too much sappy stuff with the daughter, the one-sided romance and the constant half focused, half scared look on the main female protagonists' face. The unrealistic lack of cooperation between similar research teams, the lack of depth in approaching the challenges and downright weird strategies to encounter the aliens did not help the plot forward. The aliens were boring, treelike creatures. Why bother showing up? Still, I get why the movie got high reviews. It is somewhat entertaining and definitely different. Overall, not a winner for me. Two stars is fair, I think.

This is one of those rare movies where it exceeds its source material. The theme of time is incredibly well represented and it really comes together at the end. A dazzling sci-fi epic that creates a beautiful spectacle on such a grand scale out of the mere arrival of extraterrestrial visitors. The arrivers feel truly.....well...alien. Amy Adams is sympathetic, albeit a bit on the meeker side for someone who's such an accomplished scientific figure. But still an engaging performance nonetheless. My only major issue is the ending resolution, where it's revealed that (SPOILERS!) Amy Adams's character knew that her daughter was going to die of cancer and cause her husband to leave in grief, yet still chooses to go along with it anyway because it's "worth it". Which is frustrating, because I could easily see this working if this was the only way she could preserve peace between Earth and the aliens via those time visions she received. But the movie implies that she still has the choice to not go through with it. That she merely chooses to do so out of some forced attachment to an imaginary daughter that she only saw for a couple of visions, some of which involved her in immense pain and grief during her final years of life. It almost comes across as some unsettling warped pro-life angle to this messed up scenario. Why give someone life if you know they're going to die a horrible death in their youth and cause so much misery? Why not just adopt? There's not even abortion involved, it's just the absence of procreation. And this all could've been avoided if they just implied that this had to happen, that this wasn't her choice. It would've made the ending that mirrors the beginning so much more powerful with the movie's themes about time being a circle. I know it's just one flaw, but it's a major one that really drags down the movie's otherwise fantastic score for me. Regardless, the visual artistry and alien linguistics plotline more than make up for the movie's drawbacks. A skyrocketing experience like no other.

Some claim that Denis Villeneuve is the new Christopher Nolan. Admittedly, both clearly have a drive for the extraordinary. But a look beneath the surface shows that the two directors can hardly be compared. While Nolan repeatedly overdoes it with his penchant, as he did most recently with Tenet, Villeneuve's Arrival shows that, as a presumed Nolan counterpart, he takes a completely different approach. In contrast to Nolan's repetitive brainfuck, the Canadian created what is arguably one of the most intelligent sci-fi films of recent years.

What Villeneuve clearly has ahead of Nolan is his knack with the ensembles in his films. No actress could have embodied the lead role of linguist Louise Banks better than Amy Adams. Although Jeremy Renner and Forest Whitaker are also likable in the supporting roles of a physicist and military colonel, Adams carries the film single-handedly. The character is fragile and conflicted from the start, and because of intimate glimpses into her private and thought life, we always know why that is. The way Adams manages to suggest this rollercoaster ride of emotions is quite great. She usually has barely seconds to catch her breath before she has to move on from profound thoughts about her deceased daughter back to the mysterious enigma of the aliens landing on Earth. Even the way Adams behaves in some scenes while trying to communicate with the mysterious beings is comprehensible. You immediately want to join her and assist in the difficult research. This makes for a complex film character with numerous facets that you can empathise with at all times. Yes, Adams often plays the broken woman with a dark past. Only in Arrival she certainly doesn't always come across as an emotional wreck, but rather determined and enthusiastic about her responsibility despite her stroke of fate. Jeremy Renner's character, the physicist Ian Donnelly, is a nice touch and shares many interesting scenes with Louise. However, he is overshadowed by Adam throughout. This has little to do with Renner's performance, which is excellent as always, but the character simply lacks complexity. The same applies to Whitaker's Colonel Weber, who, after an initially strong presence, plays second fiddle more and more as time goes on. This is also less due to Whitaker's acting than to the lack of X-factor in his character.

So why is Arrival now so much more thoughtful and better than, say, Tenet? Villeneuve shows such a fine hand in his directing that the film never comes across like one of the many forced sci-fi flicks with mega effects and explosions, but rather resembles a slowly told thriller. Not because there is so much suspense, Arrival is no Sicario by any means, but until the end you don't know what the aliens' intention is and to what extent the protagonist's life plays a role. The final leaves you stunned, amazed and above all overwhelmed. Despite a few hangs in the middle, Arrival is another Villeneuve masterpiece with which the best director of our time revolutionised science fiction with his unique signature.

Denis Villeneuve is one of the outstanding directors working today, consistently producing brilliant films one after the other, but Arrival may just be his most heartfelt to date.

His direction is fantastic by taking the sci fi genre and giving it new light. This film is all about communication and how language impacts how we live life, so by conveying this message through the use of aliens invading earth (a cliche narrative choice with Sci Fi) Villeneuve is risking being ordinary, but becomes an original, imaginative filmmaker in the process.

The film has excellent performances from Amy Adama and Jeremy Renner, alongside it's beautiful cinematography and soundtrack shot by Bradford Young and composed by Jóhann Jóhannsson respectively. The incredible screenplay via Eric Heisserer puts the cherry on top. An all round complete picture.

The film has many deep meanings which would suggest multiple viewings are essential in understanding the films complete idea, but Arrival is an underrated gem in my opinion and highlights Villeneuve's status as one of Hollywood's prominent directors working today.

When strange objects appear on earth, Amy Adams' linguistic professor is sent to aid the effort to understand who the visitors are, and what they want. I don't think this movie is about that "what makes us human". Personally I think it is about creating your own reality. The whole movie developes around the ability of a character to understand a language. In a way, Adams' character is a child (humanity) learning to speak. She has to go through all the tribulations of learning a new language, a powerful one at that. The premise is quite interesting and it took me two views to get it: Your language (the way you express what you think) determines your reality. They even mention it at the beginning of the movie, with the Sapir-Whorf theory. This is by far a very metaphysical proposal, and a very adecuate one at that, one that has been told to us by great master of ancient ("For by your words you will be justified, and by your words you will be condemned"). In a way, language IS reality, it is the only way we have to describe it and thus create it. So it would make sense that a more powerful language would create a different, more powerful reality. In the movie, learning the aliens' language would opne the doors of time and space for you, and this can be wither a weapon (as first understood by humans) or a gift, as later realized by Adams. Of course the ability to thread between past, present and future could be a powerful weapon, or a great gift. Once she realizes this, it is quite interesting that she still chooses to have her baby, aware of the outcome, but the most important choice she makes, while having the ability to visit the past or future, is to live in the present. Powerful message indeed. So now you know, choose your words carefully.

This is one of the coolest movies I've ever seen, and I'm old enough to have seen most of them. I feel sorry for those who call it boring because, if you truly were bored, you either didn't understand it, you have a short attention span and can only focus long enough to see movement and shiny things, or you have no feelings. Either way, you are disadvantaged and the poorer for missing out on appreciating one of the most profound films ever produced. Why is it a good film? First, there are no films that defy being categorized like this one. Sure, it's called a science fiction but, honestly, its way more than that.  In terms of a genre, it's actually a combination of a science fiction with squid monsters, an intellectual study on communication and how it might affect your thoughts and actions, an exploration into the nature of time and its perception, a commentary on human behavior and the state of mankind such as man's tendency to jump to conclusions and make rash decisions, a mystery to be solved, a romance, a story of great grief and loss and, finally and most importantly, a bitter sweet statement on the value and beauty of life, all life, even life that doesn't last that, in the end, includes everyone's life.  Secondly, Arrival does all of these things very well and weaves each element together seamlessly into something beautiful and thought provoking.  It makes a statement like a philosopher.  Like a great poem or piece of art, it forces one to think, to wonder, to feel, to understand love, to feel grief and loss, to ponder what is and what is important.  I'm richer for having seen it and I give credit to those who achieved it.  I can't believe they were able to do it and to do it so well.

Greatly expanding upon Ted Chiang's original (and terribly titled) novella, Villeneuve's thoughtful, laconic adaptation shifts the focus ever so slightly away from the heptapods themselves and their language toward the human characters and their communicative failures. In developing the social and geopolitical implications of the alien's arrival while simplifying the actual linguistic import of the source material, the film deepens the emotional resonance of the story beyond the original text's meticulous exploration of the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis; instead, here the arrival of extreme alterity could just as well stand for the need to address the exigency of unthinkable climate change (incomprehensible yet demanding response) as it does the appearance of extra terrestrials. In this sense, the movie is also ultimately far more hopeful than the novella: As in the latter, we may never fully be able to communicate with the wholly Other, understanding their motives or plans, but here we can still at least learn to speak and listen to one another.

Everything about Arrival is excellent. From the very first moments of contact, this scenario screams 'real'. Or, if not real, then at the very least 'plausible'.

Out of all the science fiction movies I've watched over the years, Arrival is the only one to evoke any sense of actual believability. If an alien species were to visit earth, the events portrayed in Arrival are almost exactly how I believe things would actually transpire.

All of the performances are fantastic, but Amy Adams really steals the show. Her portrayal of Louise Banks is engrossing and, again, believable. Jeremy Renner does a great job as well, but he shares so much screen time with Adams that his performance is very much understated.

I loved the sound direction for this film. I loved the sounds the aliens made, and I loved the distorted sensation that the characters were subjected to in their presence. The musical score is spot-on, as well. Tense, but not overbearing.

The aliens themselves were exactly how I would imagine aliens would actually appear: not human-like at all but, instead, strange and otherworldly and in complete defiance of anything we have ever seen.

I really enjoyed the plot of Arrival. I'm very interested in the concept of time and the flow of time and everything that it entails. The idea of an alien language being able to manipulate the flow of time is - to me - completely unique and unlike anything I'd seen or read in science fiction before. The use of flashbacks, and the eventual reveal of them being flash-forwards, was executed very well.

Arrival is one of the best science fiction films I've ever seen. It is smart, beautiful, dramatic, and thought-provoking... everything you could ask for in a movie.

This is perhaps the best sci-fi movie I've ever seen. It transcends the genre, over its storyline, evolving into something much greater than what its title, box art, posters, trailers, or any marketing materials could possibly convey. Its storyline starts out a tense first-contact-with-aliens affair, but unravels into something intricate, challenging, delicate, and utterly emotionally and intellectually compelling.

Simply put: Every aspect of this movie is impeccable. As a whole composition, Villeneuve has achieved near-perfection.

I could fawn over this story's plotline forever, but it's too special to reveal much through analysis. Trust me: It's genius. It's the movie I've basically always wanted, executed brilliantly.

The two obvious stars here are Amy Adams's performance and Denis Villeneuve's direction. Adams's performance has been much-lauded, but Villeneuve's direction cannot garner enough praise.

Direction is obviously outstanding. Scenes are expertly crafted to give the audience the best-possible perspective coming from the viewpoint of the central protagonist: Dr. Louise Banks (Amy Adams, who got robbed of her Oscar for this performance). This is so crucial: Scenes which are disorienting for Dr. Banks are disorienting on-screen; we feel the chaos surrounding; we feel her intimate confusion. Not only does this make us empathize with her character, but, in the movie, she is an expert linguist and brilliant person. This makes us, the audience, feel intelligent. For such an intelligent film, it's a real treat.

Pacing is excellent. It starts out slow and tense, but absolutely never boring. It ramps up precisely before it needs to, steadily building up to a crescendo that's so magnificent, detailing it in praise would be close to spoiling it.

The film's bleak and minimalistic aesthetic is outstanding, with sparse set pieces and dark, muted, earthy color tones both complimenting and focusing on the aliens and their spacecraft-a work of sci-fi minimalistic perfection. It's the glorious antithesis of oversaturated Michale Bay schlock (in almost every regard, really.)

The sound design, too, is brilliant. It's subtle, but captivating. Jóhann Jóhannsson's musical score perfectly compliments the aesthetic and narrative. It serves as neither background noise nor show-stealer. The non-musical sound design, however, is often breathtaking. It is brought into and out of focus with surgical precision, maintaining sublime quality throughous. But when it's in the spotlight, it elevates this movie, becoming one of the defining traits that make this one of the greatest sci-fi films ever.

My only minor complaint is backhanded praise: that this film deserves to be longer. It could easily work with an extra 30 minutes instead of having less than 2 hours of runtime. I'm loathe to imagine what might have been cut by studio executives, but relish the idea of a Director's Extended Cut. 

When I think about other minor complaints ("this one scene, that other scene, was this a plot hole or sloppy writing?") that popped into my head at one point or another, after digesting the film, in retrospect, every single one made sense. No other science-fiction film has required me to suspend my disbelief so little.

This film is nearly perfect. And I only say that to hedge my bet, because no imperfections come to mind. This film was a revelation. It was transcendental, monumental, and hopefully genre-defining.

The awesome plotline, pacing, aesthetic,  sound design, and acting (especially by Adams) are all precisely put together by Villeneuve to craft a cinematic art piece that is both immensely intellectually and emotionally compelling. It is a masterpiece, easily one of the greatest sci-fi films of all time.

- Arrival takes you out of this world and brings you home. -

After watching Arrival with my work boyfriend Ben, we had to go outside and have a smoke - and I don't even smoke.

This is one of the most intense, emotionally draining and sublime movies I have seen in YEARS. Director Denis Villeneuve (Sicario) excelled in making a film, not just about aliens, but the human desire to connect. It is fascinatingly complicated to explain, but this is what I would compare it to:

It's like watching a YouTube video that is narrated by a scientist as they describe how infinite space and time is and how fleeting our lives are - all whilst the most beautiful score plays in the background. I slowly fell in love with aliens and Amy Adams (Julie and Julia) and by the end of it, I questioned everything about my own existence.

I can only give a short synopsis because I don't want to reveal any major spoilers.  Here is what you need to know:

Louise (Amy Adams) is a linguistics professor who has spent her entire life studying communication. She knows about a billion different languages (don't quote me on that, it's probably more like 40). In the opening scenes of Arrival, 12 alien spaceships land all over the world and Louise is called upon to communicate with the one that landed in America. What happens next is a space roller coaster of emotion, science, math and language.

That's about all I can tell you about the plot. Not because I am lazy, but because I want you to experience what I did - going into a movie you know very little about.

So instead, I will tell you about the rest of my evening as we tried to make sense of what we'd just seen.

Ben and I sat on the bench outside the theater with our legs folded.  We gushed with mutual revelations of "Oh god I didn't even pick up on that."

Ben asked me "How on Earth (pun intended) are you going to review this?" I shrugged my shoulders and said, "maybe I will write it in the symbols that the aliens used to communicate with humans, but then I realized I am not a linguistics expert or an alien, so that idea was quickly abandoned.

However, I feel that I am an expert in spotting talent and Amy Adams has been on my radar for awhile now. We discussed how I thought she was a great actress but the characters she's played in the past have annoyed the living crap out of me. But there was no such annoyance in sight with her portrayal of Louise in Arrival. Adams plays her exquisitely.

There is no dramatic speech about "this is our Independence Day." She doesn't scream and cry that the world is ending. Adams subtly and superbly plays a woman who is hiding a secret but doesn't know it. Adams is so good in fact, she had me singing "somebody is getting an Oscar nomination" all the way to my car.

The last thing I did with my evening was call my mum, because this movie makes you want to call your family. If you don't have a family, then it will make you call your friends. If you don't have friends, then it will make you search the skies for aliens to talk to.

Why? Because this epic Sci-Fi film is not really about the threat of aliens, it is about communication. It is about understanding each other and our differences. We are all asking the questions, do you hear me? Do you see me? Does what I am saying matter to you?

After watching Arrival, it was not a question of are we alone in the universe, it was a question of, why would we want to be? And if there is ever a day when extraterrestrials come down to Earth, if I'm still alive, then I will be the first to shake their hand - or tentacle - or whatever.

As famous philosopher Paulo Freire once said - "only through communication can human life hold meaning". Therefore isn't the meaning of life found through how we connect with each other, through love and understanding? (Woah, wait...did I just discover the meaning of life?)

Arrival is a love letter to language. "Language is the foundation of civilization. It is the glue that holds a people together. It is the first weapon drawn in a conflict." Is the first line in a book by the main character who is a linguist given the duty of translating the language of an alien species. The real main character of the film is the Sappir-Whorf hypothesis which states that how we think is informed by our language. In the film one of the ways a nation tried to teach the aliens language is through the use of Shogi which is a Chess like game. If the aliens are only taught words related to a competitive game then they can only describe things in terms of competition. As the film puts it "Give them a hammer and everything is a nail" It makes the audience consider how language has effected our perspective and how we might be limited by it. What would a language look like if it had no limits and caused our perspective to shift in the direction of infinity? Words are intended to represent concepts, causality is a concept at the root of making predictions, if we understood causality perfectly and codified that understanding into language then we could accurately make predictions. In the film the aliens possess such a language and as a result predict the future.

Arrival is a misleading movie. The film will make you think one thing and then another, all while having a great cast and a weak story. Arrival is probably one of my least favorite movies of 2016, which I haven't watched until now. Here is my non-spoiler review of Arrival.

9/10 points go to the ACTING category. Amy Adams, Jeremy Renner, Forrest Whitaker, and friends give great performances. Adams makes a convincing character who's name I have already forgotten. Renner plays Ian, who is the only reason there is one point off from this category. He literally gives a stupid and idiotic delivery for his last line of the film. I won't say it, as it is a spoiler to the end.

4/15 points goes to the WRITING category. The story is basic. Weird aliens come to Earth, people want to know what they are, and Amy Adams is seeing stuff she can't explain. The first 30 minutes of the film and any sequence with the aliens is amazing. The rest is pretty bad. History is determined, but Adams doesn't know what to do/say. Adams is seeing stuff, but doesn't even care about what it is. There are even parts where it seems like present and unknown tense are coming together. The story is not written to well.

10/10 points go to the VISUAL EFFECTS category. The aliens look real, and so do the shells. No problems here like about everything else.

4/10 points go to the CHARACTERS category. The characters are basic. We get little development from them. There is a tiny bit of development for Adams and Ian, but I won't tell you because it is a spoiler. Many people can only be called "people who scream and complain a lot", which is pretty basic.

2/5 points go to the DEVELOPMENT category. There is a bit of a conflict and a bit of a compromise. There is a bit of an answer to a question that doesn't get answered. There are a lot of plot holes. This movie also, as I previously said, has a bit of character development which is a spoiler.

2/5 points go to the ORIGINAL MUSIC SCORE category. The score is basic, it is very noticeable most of the time, and that is a bad thing. I didn't find the score at all or even a bit interesting. 

3/5 points go to the DESIGN category. The design in a bit cool I guess. It is a bit original and is a bit lame at the same time. It is pretty dark sometimes, and I don't like that. I like the movie's way of showing that things are a bit rushed within the way that things are unorganized. I don't know if that was or wasn't untended by the director.

10/10 points go to the DIRECTION category. Everything that seems planned is done well. Most of the delivery is pretty good. Yeah. That's about all I have to say about the direction of this movie. Nothing stands out.

4/10 points go to the VISION AND SOUND QUALITY category. You can barely hear the actors for most of the movie. The movie is very dark for many scenes which is pretty bad. Some of the scenes do look good. The editing is also pretty bad for most of the film's random vision scenes that Adams is having.

7/20 points go to the MY OVERALL CONSENSUS category. The film is boring, seems unorganized, and overall, I thought it was pretty bad.

I hereby officially announce the beginning of the Oscar race, let the fight begin! It took a while this year! Gosh, as soon as this movie arrives it begs to be praised and saying what makes it good is as easy as understanding quantum physics. First of all, you have to understand that, more than anything, this is a character study. No, it's not a movie about aliens, an invasion, or even a conflict between beings from outer space and humans. It's primarily about a character and her inner conflict and psyche. We're start to finish with Louise to learn of what she makes of what's happening around her and how that is changing her. This is done beautifully in Sicario and in that sense it seems pretty similar the way we follow Kate (from Sicario) and Louise, making sure that we're constantly enthralled in order to understand them. This is done by shifting a little bit of the attention from what surrounds Louise to her expression and by having a performance to match it. No surprise there, but Amy Adams just blows it out of the park giving a subtle and realistic performance that is absolutely translucent to the character's inner state. Many haven't noticed, but Amy is the new Leo, having 5 nominations and no win but this season, whether with this one or Nocturnal Animals, I believe she has a good shot of getting that gold! Furthermore, this film not only has a fantastically substantiated script and plot, but also has the technical side to support it: the cinematography is rich and very identifiable, the sound design is well thought out and the aliens and ship's design is marvellous. The music is also close to perfection as Jóhannsson accentuates and gives even more meaning to important moments, and keeps quiet when he should. I also like that this movie takes such a fresh approach to the genre, as it manages to make a film about a translator actually damn gripping! I'm a fan of this trend of intellectual astute sci-fi movies that is being developed recently. And like Interstellar, this one comes with an even better grounded and believable twist.  The end gives meaning to the film, making it more than just about some aliens, but about communication, loss and the way we conceive time. Never this year have I felt the need to see a film exactly after I saw it and Arrival is, undoubtedly, the best movie I saw this post-Oscar year. Please, if there's a movie to spend money on right now, this is it!

At its core Arrival is not an alien movie but, as the featured image suggests, a human movie. It's a movie about the power of humanity and our need to overcome divisive rhetoric and fear in order to survive. It's especially poignant in the current U.S. political climate, when it's not difficult to imagine a historically significant event bringing us to the edge of catastrophe.

It's hard to find fault in any aspect of this movie, so instead, I'll stick to what works well. Amy Adams' initially flat performance is incredibly nuanced - don't disregard her as a contender for Best Actress. The sound mixing and score are beautifully handled, creating a space for the movie to breath and feel and exist without shoving emotions down the audience's throat. The cinematography is stunning, aided by beautiful scenery and near-flawless visual effects.

Finally, screenwriter Eric Heisserer (previously wasted on projects like The Thing and Final Destination 5) handles the source material from the sci-fi short story "Story of Your Life" with aplomb. I'm seeking out an original copy of the story now, to see how much he adapted, and how much was just not screwing it up (a real danger in Hollywood these days, no matter the quality of the source).

I'm on the edge of my seat eager for the Academy Award nominations (three days!) to see how many Arrival pulls in. Simultaneously, it won't surprise me if this low-budget, indie film is too nuanced to get the recognition it deserves. Never fear - I may not be the Academy or Roger Ebert, but this movie has my full endorsement.

The Arrival of a Lifetime

In Denis Villeneuve's movie, Arrival, linguist Louise Banks (Amy Adams) is the United States' last hope to prevent a catastrophic world war. Upon the arrival of 12 massive, foreign ships, the world becomes plagued with chaos and fear. Throughout this sci-fi, Inception-esc film, the unexpectant viewer is taken on a high-intensity, unpredictable, and yet, perfectly engineered rollercoaster of excitement and suspense. 

However, one cannot review this movie without mentioning the inspiration behind it: "The Story of Your Life". This is a short story novella written by Ted Chiang that is centered around language. Chiang's inspiration for this novella was the philosophical theory of free will. To incite further thoughts, Chiang poses the question, "If you know what's going to happen, can you keep it from happening?"   This century old ethical question is addressed in Chiang's novella. 


This exciting production takes place in the barren plains of Montana, where professor of linguistics Louise Banks and her team are tasked with an urgent, classified assignment. She is asked to put to test her extensive knowledge and skills of language and translation in just a short period of time; that is, before other countries lose faith in each other and begin pointing their fingers. While diligently working to complete such an extensive task, professor Banks is afflicted by an unknown, futuristic paradigm of what language will entail one day. However, it becomes apparent that the extraterrestrials haven't come for any reason other than to save themselves. 

This review, while not full of complete story lines and time frames, is in simple words, a spoiler. 

The method the extraterrestrials use to save themselves is unexpected by most viewers. This large-scale theme is perfectly illustrated in a single scene. The scene commences with an unauthorized military man entering the alien ship and placing C4 within the chamber of communication. Without this knowledge, Dr. Banks and her associate, Ian Donnelly (Jeremy Renner), rush to the pod in attempt to decipher the alien language. As the C4 explosive is about to detonate, the alien sacrifices itself to preserve the life of Dr. Banks and Ian Donnelly. Ironically, however, Dr. Banks is the only person capable of deciphering, understanding, and later, teaching this completely foreign language. Even more so, it is precisely this language that will save the alien species from utter extinction by allowing those who know such language to see the future.  

With this ability to see into the future, the viewer finally comes to an understanding of the continuous, what-seem-to-be flashbacks troubling Dr. Banks. Indeed, such visions are not flashbacks by any sense of word; they are, in fact, the polar opposite: flash-forwards. Throughout the entirety of the movie, Dr. Banks develops a continuously growing knowledge of the alien language and, for that reason begins to see into the future, which contains glimpses of her current unborn daughter. 

These reoccurring visions illustrate a deep sense of humility and maturity in Louise Banks. Knowing that her daughter is going to be born with a terminal illness, she happily accepts fate and looks forward to cherishing every moment with her future daughter. Beyond that, if this language allows for future knowledge, the extraterrestrials' knowledge is no confined to time. Simply put, they know their future. They know that C4 is going to explode and injure them. However, just like Louise Banks, they knowingly accept this fate. 

With a language like this, what is the limit? When knowledge isn't limited to the bounds of time who's to say what can and cannot be accomplished? On the other side, are humans mature and moral enough to accept this almost all-empowering language? This also alludes to Ted Chiang's novella and the inspiration behind it. Exists free will? If so, can one prevent the known future? All of these are questions that rise from this movie. 

Because of these "flash-forwards", Arrival takes on this Inception-like plot twist at the end. It is truly intriguing. Inception was a dream within a dream, induced by a particular party of interest, and used to influence a man's decision for the party's own benefit. Likewise, Arrival is a flash-forward, revealed by the extraterrestrials to Dr. Banks for their own interest. The reason the aliens show her these "flash-forwards" is to merely convince her to learn their language and therefore, be the architect of their future salvation. 

Regardless of comparisons, this was a perfectly executed film. How often does one witness a professor of linguistics as a "save-the-day", hero type character in a movie? On top of that, the portrayal of genuine, pleasant aliens is a scarce sight in today's world. Although their actions reflected self-indulged motives, the extraterrestrials came to give humanity a tool: their language. 

While completely enthralled by this film, certain questions came to mind. What happens to humanity over the next 3000 years, prior to the saving of these aliens? How does their language affect modern society and technology? What was so strong as to threaten the existence of these advanced extraterrestrials 3000 years from the time of the film? Of course, being a science fiction enthusiast, the idea of a sequel, prequel, or anything in-between this movie's timeline is captivating.     

All in all, this brilliant depiction of extraterrestrials and linguistics merged together forms what is now one of the most authentic, captivating films within the science fiction genre. In a single word, brilliant. This movie was nothing short of brilliance. The original integration of a linguist savior for an alien species is captivating, exciting, and refreshing.

The name Denis Villeneuve is quickly becoming synonymous with great films. The man who directed Sicario, Prisoners, and Blade Runner 2049, brought us this smart tale of humans attempting to communicate with aliens. The premise sees a linguist (Amy Adams) and physicist (Jeremy Renner) work together with the government in an attempt to communicate with the invaders from another world. I appreciated that the story focused on that aspect instead of some fight with the other beings. The fact that we never know what the aliens or military members with Adams and Renner would do, made for some great tense scenes. There's a particular one with a ticking bomb that stood out as excellent. Adams shines above everything else with one of the best performances of her career. She portrays her desperation to understand these creatures, in the midst of some haunting visions, expertly. She and Renner played off each other well. There are some pacing issues, as things moved at a crawl in a few of the scenes towards the middle, but it picks up with a great ending. The twist is fantastic, though once it becomes clear they still wait a bit to reveal a bit of an obvious part. An original take on the alien concept, beautifully shot and handled by a skilled director and led by top notch actors.

Smart and visually arresting science fiction tale about earth's first contact with aliens. Mysterious floating monoliths appear around the world and linguist Amy Adams, with help of physicist Jeremy Renner, work with the government to try and communicate with the aliens amid global fears and international political tensions. This story is more "Close Encounters" and "Contact" than "Independence Day" or "War of the Worlds," where the main focus of the story is on how to communicate with the aliens, while reassuring the military brass, primarily Forrest Whittaker, that everything is okay and they don't have to attack. This tension of whether they can successfully communicate and avert a conflict with this new species (and whether other countries around the world might tip off an interstellar as well) makes for good ticking time bomb of dramatic tension, but it's really Adams who give the film an emotional human center, desperately wanting to connect with to these advances creatures, while at the same time is haunted by visions of her daughter. Directed by Denis Villeneuve, who's next project was the new Blade Runner film, brings a strong visual style to the proceeding, but never in a way that is distracting to the story or style for the sake of style. My only complaint about the film is that it does move at a rather glacial pace, though in the end, the film does deliver with a terrific mind-bending of an ending, that makes the wait well worth it. Overall, "Arrival" is not a film for anyone wanting slam-bang science fiction, but is great if you're in the mood for something along the lines of "Solaris" or "Moon."

This movie was amazing. It was absolutely beautiful and so unlike the dystopian alien massacre movies that dominate this category. It was refreshing and captivating- near perfect. I would highly suggest watching this movie if you want to feel both inspired and challenged. It's not as predictable as a lot of other mainstream movies; they give you just enough plot points and knowledge to follow a thread but not enough to draw all-telling solid conclusions (most of the time). The only major thing I had an issue with was:
**Warning: major spoiler ahead!**
The fact that Ian left Louise over something so petty!
I say 'petty' rightfully because this is an advanced scientist who has openly communicated with aliens, defied gravity, and knows that Louise can see the future (because obviously you don't just shield someone from a bullet while you listen to them speak Mandarin and save the world without questioning their actions later). 
He is this accepting of everything around him but yet he simply can't accept that his daughter will die early of cancer? We all die in the end- does that make life pointless or does it free us to enjoy what we have? If our lives were already written out would that make our actions hollow or valuable experiences we should really give ourselves into?
It really surprised me that a man of his understanding, acceptance, and intelligence left Louise over the pain of knowing his daughter will die early of cancer- and that Louise chose to have her anyways.
Most parents wouldn't trade anything in the world for even a minute of their child's life- would he have rather not had her at all than get to enjoy her beautiful life and fill his heart with love for her? 
I mean I get his divorce from her is used as a plot device to 1. Keep the pieces of the story from coming together too quickly, and 2. To demonstrate to the audience that things like the probability/knowing of death and heart break shouldn't keep us from following our hearts. 
BUT STILL. It pisses me off. I hate that such a seemingly deep character made such a shallow choice. Hannah always has been, and always will be theirs. Nothing in the world could've ever changed that- dead or alive, she always belonged to them. Before she had even existed she was theirs. 
e.g.
I wouldn't say I made the wrong choice picking my dog out as a puppy if I knew he was going to die of a degenerative disease 13 years later. I love him more than I can handle, and he will always hold a piece of my heart. Forever. No dog I would've picked out would live for eternity- and would I sacrifice the love I have for him specifically and the life he's lead for the sake of avoiding heartbreak? Never. 
You can't fight life- you can only embrace it and accept it for what it is.

Arrival is a really neat idea for a film. A language professor must communicate with aliens that have arrived, and figure out why they're here. The film has some stellar acting, and a neat premise. The payoff, however...well, you'll see.

The process of the first two-thirds of the movie is really neat. The slow build-up of understanding the language is shown very well, with Adams giving a great performance. I also enjoy the interplay between her and Forest Whitaker, the career army man.

I take issue with Jeremy Renner's character. It is not made plain in the entire film why he is there. He's supposed to a scientist, and he is shown doing scientisty things, but they have no effect whatsoever on the plot. It might have been a good idea to pull back the focus to flesh out the mission a little more.

Once we get to the third act, the big sci-fi reveal happens. Here's the problem: you've already established a certain level of strangeness in the film, and this third act adds a whole new layer. It really pulls the rug out from under you. It might work for someone who was ready for that level of sci-fi, but I was not. It got really complex, really fast, and I felt whiplash while watching it.

It left a bad taste in my mouth, and looking back now a few weeks later, doesn't seem as egregious (hence the largely-positive rating). In the moment, it really took me out, though.

I don't even remember the last time I give 5.0 out of 5.0 rating for a film on RottenTomatoes, but the film "Arrival" definitely deserves this perfect rating. Seeing this film is like discovering a holy grail for students and fans of linguistics alike. As a polyglot, I love being able to see a sci-fi depicting a linguist trying to figure out an alien's language and the consequences of being able to communicate in their language.

I profoundly appreciate the fact that Hollywood is able to explore the theme of alien visitation without having to rehash the heap of manure in form of "Alien Attacks!!!" or how an "American Superhero saves the world from those alien overlords!!!" that has oversaturated the monde of American films in recent decades.

Amy Adams' emotional performance as the linguist (and as the only character who matters in the film, really) also helps to bridge the aliens to humans...and bridge the aliens' language to the viewers of the film.

In a way, this cerebral theme of alien sci-fi is reminiscent of Interstellar (except for the fact that the "alien" in Interstellar is of a completely different entity...I don't want to reveal spoilers here), in a way that the opening of the film provides major clues to the key of the plot.

Because, as the film "Arrival" reveals later on, the key to life and everything else may lie closer to us than we think.
